abstract.p: Holland Cotter reviews 19th- and 20th-century works on paper at Dickinson Roundell's new Manhattan gallery (S)

block.p: Dickinson Roundell, the New York branch of a London-based gallery group, has inaugurated its new Manhattan space with this group exhibition, which is about as glamorous as gallery roundups get.
Chronologically, the lineup starts with a postcardish Delacroix watercolor of a Moroccan woman done in 1832, and ends with a small, tissuey Agnes Martin piece from 1977.
Dickinson Roundell, the New York branch of a London-based gallery group, has inaugurated its new Manhattan space with this group exhibition, which is about as glamorous as gallery roundups get.
Chronologically, the lineup starts with a postcardish Delacroix watercolor of a Moroccan woman done in 1832, and ends with a small, tissuey Agnes Martin piece from 1977.

Among landscape images in between, three are neck-and-neck favorites: a Cezanne watercolor of chestnut trees, all space and light; a dashing little Pissarro view of Louveciennes, and a van Gogh pencil sketch of a field seen from his hospital window at St. Remy, with tufts of grass-like explosions.

There are some marvelous portraits. Degas's 1867 drawing of the wistful, moon-faced Mme. Gaujelin is matched in its cool sensuality by a muscle-perfect depiction of a race horse from a few years later. Picasso's very early portrait of his friend Josep Cardona is all glum Romantic self-importance, while James Tissot's high-polish watercolor version of an oil painting depicts a tired-looking model holding a flower between her teeth.

Two beautiful Kurt Schwitters collages, dense with fabric and paint, take the show beyond the traditional works-on-paper category, as does a Paul Klee oil painting of colored bands spinning off into darkness.
And with Lucio Fontana's oval of blotting paper pierced by jagged holes, we are in the realm of sculpture.
In short, no theme or focus here, just dozens of world-class items brought together, briefly and free for the looking, under one roof.
